title: Athletics coach faces doping claims
desc: One of the world's best known athletics coaches is at the centre of doping allegations according to a BBC investigation.

title: Heavy fighting rages in east Ukraine
desc: Fierce fighting is raging between Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine despite a truce deal officials on both sides say.

title: Blatter given ovation by Fifa staff
desc: Emotional Fifa president Sepp Blatter is given a 10-minute standing ovation by 400 staff as he returns to its Zurich HQ after saying he will quit.

title: US: 10000 IS militants killed
desc: More than 10000 Islamic State fighters have been killed since a US-led coalition launched a campaign against it nine months ago the US says.

title: Greek plea for EU unity before talks
desc: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras urges Europe's leaders to show unity and realism ahead of a key Brussels meeting on solving Greece's debt crisis.

title: French tests on 359-year-old body
desc: French scientists carry out tests and a post-mortem examination on the remarkably well-preserved body of a 17th Century woman found in the south-western city of Rennes.

title: Hopes fade in Yangtze boat rescue
desc: Divers spend the night searching a cruise ship which capsized in China's Yangtze River but the death toll rises to 18 and hundreds are still missing.

title: Nigeria army accused of suspect deaths
desc: More than 7000 men and boys have died in Nigerian military custody during its fight against Boko Haram says Amnesty International.

title: Egypt police killed in Giza attack
desc: Gunmen shoot dead two Egyptian policemen on a road leading to the Giza pyramids in a rare attack at a tourist site.

title: India bans Maggi noodles in Delhi
desc: Authorities in the Indian capital ban sale of Maggi noodles for 15 days after high levels of lead are found in batches tested in Delhi and Uttar Pradesh.

title: Apple boss hits out at rival firms
desc: Tim Cook makes a thinly veiled attack on Facebook and Google for gobbling up user data.

title: Iglesias injury 'worse than expected'
desc: Enrique Iglesias who sliced his fingers on a drone will need extra time to recuperate after it is discovered his injuries are worse than expected.

title: VIDEO: Face-to-face with Islamic State militants
desc: The BBC's Orla Guerin is given exclusive access to members of an alleged Islamic State militant cell.

title: VIDEO: Forensic teams gather at Yangtze site
desc: John Sudworth watches as the Chinese authorities prepare to recover bodies from a capsized boat on the Yangtze River.

title: VIDEO: Dawn of a new era in physics?
desc: The world's most powerful particle accelerator the Large Hadron Collider is returning to full operations after a two year upgrade.

title: VIDEO: Would you wear your phone's charger?
desc: Cindy Sui visits the Computex technology show in Taiwan and sees some of the latest gadgets including a wearable charger.

title: VIDEO: US man escapes from sinking truck
desc: A Californian man escapes from his sinking truck after reportedly failing to properly detach his boat from it at a launch in Santa Barbara.

title: VIDEO: Pele & New York Cosmos visit Cuba
desc: BBC Sport's Alex South reports as the Cuban national team play a friendly against New York Cosmos in Havana.

title: VIDEO: Slaves who died in shipwreck remembered
desc: A ceremony has taken place in South Africa to remember the slaves who died when a ship transporting them from Mozambique to Brazil sank close to Cape Town.

title: VIDEO: Secret tests show US airport security lapses
desc: A top US official has pledged reforms after tests found that airport screeners allowed mock explosives and weapons through security checkpoints 95% of the time.

title: Eurozone still in denial about Greece
desc: Even if Greece and its creditors agree a temporary rescue this week the really hard negotiation on how to rescue the Greek economy is yet to be had.

title: Questions raised over Eastern Star
desc: The BBC's Jo Floto in Beijing delves into the many questions raised by Eastern Star's capsizing in the Yangtze River.

title: What will Opec do about the oil supply?
desc: Oil ministers from Opec meet in Vienna this week to decide whether to cut output or keep pumping crude oil into a market that is already oversupplied.

title: VIDEO: Ebola: Health tips for survivors
desc: Health experts offer tips and advice for Ebola survivors.

title: FIFA extradition and Blatter: How will it play out?
desc: Seven Fifa officials are facing extradition to the US on corruption charges. How does extradition between the US and Switzerland work?

title: VIDEO: HK students boycott Tiananmen vigil
desc: For the first time a key pro-democracy group the Hong Kong Federation of Students will not be taking part in commemorating the anniversary of Tiananmen Square.

title: 'Underweight model' advert banned
desc: An Yves Saint Laurent advertisement featuring an unhealthily underweight model is banned by the Advertising Standards Authority.

title: Godzilla finally gets citizenship in Japan
desc: Meet Japan's newest official resident: Godzilla

title: OECD slashes US growth forecast
desc: The OECD slashes its US growth forecast for this year and next and given the global economy a B minus in its bi-annual assessment.

title: ECB: Eurozone recovery to broaden
desc: The European Central Bank says the eurozone's recovery is expected to broaden as it raises its inflation projections for 2015.

title: Flight booking sites made to add fee
desc: Lufthansa Group is making online-booking services including Opodo and Expedia add a surcharge to encourage people to use its own site.

title: Fallout 4 confirmed for release
desc: A new instalment in the best-selling post-apocalyptic video game series Fallout is confirmed.

title: Senegal singer 'had fake millions'
desc: Senegalese singer Thione Seck is charged with money laundering after fake banknotes worth millions of dollars were found in his house.

title: Suffragette to open London film event
desc: This year's London Film Festival will open with the period drama Suffragette it has been announced.

title: Solar plane suffers wing damage
desc: A solar-powered plane that is attempting a record-breaking flight around the world has suffered damage after an unscheduled stop in Japan.

title: Hadron collider turns on data tap
desc: The Large Hadron Collider has re-started scientific investigations after a two-year pause.

title: S Korea has first two Mers deaths
desc: Two people die of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) in South Korea - the first fatalities from the disease officials say.

title: Canada tobacco firms to pay damages
desc: A Canadian court orders three tobacco companies to pay C$15.5bn (Â£8bn $12bn) - the largest award for damages in the country's history.

title: Djokovic beats Nadal in straight sets
desc: Novak Djokovic becomes only the second man to beat Rafael Nadal at the French Open with an emphatic victory.

title: Murray sees off Ferrer to make semis
desc: Andy Murray beats David Ferrer for the first time on clay to set up a French Open semi-final against Novak Djokovic.

title: Drips leaks and blocked drains in chic Paris
desc: Paris is a beautiful city but much of its housing stock is in poor condition notes Hugh Schofield himself the victim of a series of plumbing disasters.

title: Listening to the language of apes
desc: The similarities between apes and people have long fascinated scientists. Yet writes Mary Colwell the differences can be just as thrilling.

title: Ancient pearl found in Australia
desc: Carbon dating shows a natural pearl unearthed in a remote part of western Australia is more than 2000 years old academics say.

title: Japan mulls fitting toilets in lifts
desc: Lifts could get toilets in case people are trapped by earthquakes.

title: South Africa denies World Cup bribe
desc: South Africa denies paying a $10m bribe to secure the 2010 World Cup a day after Fifa chief Sepp Blatter resigned amid a Fifa corruption scandal.

title: Writer Taslima Nasreen flees to US
desc: Award-winning Bangladeshi writer Taslima Nasreen has fled from India to the US after she was named as an al-Qaeda target a rights group says.

title: Real boss Benitez 'admires' Sterling
desc: Ex-Liverpool boss Rafael Benitez is presented as Real Madrid manager - and says he admires Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

title: Blatter 'under investigation in US'
desc: Outgoing Fifa president Sepp Blatter is being investigated by US officials as part of their inquiry into corruption US media reports say.

title: Syrians 'stranded in Jordan desert'
desc: Hundreds of Syrian refugees are stranded in remote desert areas because Jordan is restricting informal border crossings Human Rights Watch says.

title: Boston police in more terror raids
desc: Police have arrested a man in Boston hours after shooting dead a terror suspect whom they say he knew.

title: Body confirmed as missing girl
desc: A body found in a Nottinghamshire town is confirmed as missing 13-year-old Amber Peat.

title: Wells 'took drugs before medal win'
desc: A BBC investigation uncovers claims of drug taking by British 100m Olympic gold medallist Allan Wells.

title: Alton Towers accident victims named
desc: Two teenagers are named as among those injured when a rollercoaster crashed at Alton Towers.

title: NHS England targets failing services
desc: Whole areas of the NHS in England are being placed in special measures the head of the NHS announces.
